instance_metrics.response:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He wandered to the window, pulling back the dusty curtain. Below, a procession of lanterns wound through the dark, illuminating the faces of children clutching their mothers’ hands. Liza’s voice trembled as she continued. ‘We’ve survived worse. We’ll survive this, too.’

Kasim watched the street, unease flickering in his eyes. ‘You can’t guarantee that,’ he said, voice barely audible. ‘The officials will come at dawn.’

The house creaked, old beams settling. Liza touched the photograph on the mantle—a faded picture of a family picnic, long before the exodus, before the lists. She squared her shoulders. ‘We’ll hide them in the cellar. If they knock, I’ll answer. I’ll say nothing.’

Kasim turned, searching her face. ‘And what about you?’

A smile ghosted her lips. ‘I stopped being afraid a long time ago.’

As the procession passed, Liza slipped into the corridor. She would defy the order, she would shield them all, and if dawn brought consequences, so be it. Some promises were worth keeping, no matter the cost.

instance_metrics.response:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. His indifference stung, but Liza pressed on, her voice echoing in the cramped office. Outside, the sound of chanting drifted through the cracked window—neighbors, friends, all gathered to protest the removals. She looked at Kasim, once her confidant, now a bureaucrat, his badge gleaming under the fluorescent lights.

‘You remember when we hid in the school basement?’ Liza whispered, leaning closer. ‘How your mother braided your hair to keep you calm?’

Kasim’s jaw tightened. ‘That was a lifetime ago.’

‘But you remember,’ Liza insisted. ‘You know what it means to lose everything.’

He wouldn’t meet her eyes. ‘It’s not my decision.’

Liza stood, fists clenched. ‘Then make it yours. Help me.’

A long silence. Then, quietly, ‘Meet me by the loading dock at midnight. Bring only who you trust.’

Liza nodded, her resolve hardening. Tonight, she would keep her promise—no matter the price.

‘You always say that,’ he said. ‘But words won’t stop what’s coming.’

Liza stood, drawing herself to her full height. ‘Then I’ll use more than words.’

She marched to the heavy door, flung it open, and beckoned the waiting families inside. Their faces were drawn but hopeful, clutching small bags, children peeking from behind skirts. Liza’s voice rang out: ‘No one leaves this room unless they choose to. We stand together.’

Kasim closed his eyes. For a heartbeat, he seemed to waver, then followed her to the doorway. Outside, the distant sound of boots on gravel grew louder. Liza faced the oncoming storm, her vow unbroken, her courage infectious. The families gathered around her, and Kasim, at last, stood beside her, ready to face whatever came next.

But outside, the air hummed with the low static of drones circling overhead, their red lights blinking through the mist. Liza pressed the comm-link tighter to her ear, whispering, ‘I’ve secured the passage through the old aqueduct—just like the maps said.’

Kasim’s eyes darted to the ceiling, as if he could see the surveillance grid. ‘Do you know what you’re risking, Liza? If they catch you—’

‘If we do nothing, these children will lose their parents tonight,’ she replied, her tone steely. She reached into her coat and pulled out the chipped blue token, the one symbolizing safe passage. ‘We go in twenty minutes. You decide now: are you with us?’

Kasim hesitated, weighing loyalty against fear. Finally, he nodded. ‘I’ll guide them through the tunnels. But after this, I disappear.’

Liza allowed herself a rare smile. ‘No one disappears, Kasim. Not in the way they want us to.’

Outside, the city’s midnight curfew siren wailed, but inside, hope flickered and grew.

instance_metrics.response: Oh, I’m great. Really, I am. My left sock is slowly unraveling, my coffee tastes faintly of basil, and the neighbor’s cat has taken to watching me through the window with what I can only describe as predatory curiosity. Yet here I am, balancing my breakfast on one knee and reading an email from a man in Paraguay who claims to know the secret to eternal happiness. I consider replying. Maybe today is the day I fly to Asunción, trade my shoes for a pair of sapphire slippers, and join a circus of philosophers. Or maybe I’ll just patch my sock and wave at the cat. Either way, I’ll tell myself I’m great. And perhaps, by the end of the day, I’ll almost believe it.

instance_metrics.response: Oh, I’m great. I say it every morning at precisely 7:12 a.m., just as the first train rattles past my apartment and shakes the rows of porcelain dolls lined up on my kitchen shelf. They nod along, glassy-eyed and solemn, approving of my daily affirmation. Today, though, the words taste different—like burnt caramel and static. Because today, the train doesn’t come. The city hums a different tune, one where the pigeons tap out Morse code on my windowsill and the phone rings with voices I’ve never met. I put on my yellow galoshes and step outside, ready to find where the train has gone. Halfway down the block, I find tracks snaking into the clouds, and, smiling, I follow, porcelain dolls waving from my window as I disappear into the fog.

Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man—whose sunglasses seem to absorb all light—pauses, locking eyes with Jonah. Without a word, he flips a coin, its silver glinting in the sun, before catching it and tucking it into his pocket. 

“Depends what you’re trying to hide,” the man replies, his voice low and almost melodic. The Ferrari’s door closes with a muted click, as if even the car is trying not to draw attention. Jonah watches, the hairs on his arms prickling. The city’s afternoon bustle dulls, the air charged with a current he can’t quite place.

The man glances at the alley behind Jonah, then steps forward. “You got the package?”

Jonah nods, feeling the weight of the small velvet box in his jacket. He hadn’t expected a handoff to look like this, not in broad daylight, not with a car that screamed for attention. But as the man approaches, Jonah realizes some people never truly want to disappear. They just want you to think they could, if they wanted.

“Only the best camouflage,” he replies, voice smooth as lacquer. The onlookers’ gazes follow him, mesmerized. Jonah feels out of place in his battered sneakers and thrift-store jacket, suddenly aware of the dirt under his fingernails. 

“Did you bring it?” the man asks, drawing closer. Jonah nods, producing a crumpled envelope from his pocket. The man takes it, sliding it into his jacket without breaking stride. 

“You’ll get your answer by midnight,” he whispers, before disappearing into the crowd as if he’d never been there. The Ferrari sits gleaming behind Jonah, too bold and beautiful for the quiet street. Jonah exhales, heart pounding, and wonders how something so loud could make him feel so invisible.

Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man’s shoes, polished to a mirror shine, click against the cobblestone street. He surveys the small cafe with an air of mild disdain before meeting Jonah’s gaze. 

“Life’s too short for subtlety,” the man replies, tucking a gold cufflink back into place. He glances at the Ferrari, then at Jonah, as if calculating the precise effect his entrance has made. 

Jonah sips his coffee, trying to stifle a laugh. He’s never understood people like this—who wear their wealth like armor. But the man slides into the chair opposite him, all practiced grace, and leans in. 

“You have the documents?” he asks, voice barely above a whisper. 

Jonah nods and pushes a slim folder across the table. “You know, a Prius would’ve drawn less attention.”

The man smiles, eyes glinting. “But then you wouldn’t be sure you’ve met the right person.”

Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The stranger grins, his reflection rippling across the car’s crimson curve. “I find it best to let the world know I’ve arrived.”

Jonah shrugs, shifting his backpack. They stand in the shadow of the art museum, where marble lions keep silent watch. The man approaches, each step measured, as if he’s walked this tightrope a thousand times. 

“Do you have the painting?” the man asks, his eyes flicking toward Jonah’s pack.

Jonah hesitates, glancing at passing tourists. “I do. But I need your word—no police, no tricks.”

The man laughs, low and easy. “Jonah, if I wanted trouble, I’d have brought a limo.”

Jonah unzips his bag, heart hammering, and wonders if sometimes the loudest thing you can do is act like you have nothing to hide at all.

Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man’s mouth quirks up at one corner, not quite a smile, as he pauses to adjust an emerald green scarf looped jauntily around his neck. “It’s my grandmother’s,” he replies, voice silky with mischief. “She insisted I take it for the grocery run.”

Jonah raises an eyebrow, but before he can reply, the man produces a battered violin case from the passenger seat. Out of place among the sleek lines and gleaming chrome, the case looks almost ancient. He slides it across the hood toward Jonah, fingers never leaving the handle.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The echoing clangs reverberated through the airlock, disturbing the delicate silence that had settled since the alarms first blared. Outside the viewport, the swirling green nebula pulsed with an unnatural light, casting sickly shadows across Reggie’s face. Hardy’s eyes, mechanical irises flickering, betrayed none of the fear that gripped his organic companion.

“Just keep calm,” Hardy’s voice modulated, an attempt at reassurance. “We’ve survived worse.”

Reggie’s knees knocked together. “This is worse!” he hissed. “Did you see those… those things?”

Hardy’s fist dented the bulkhead again. “I’m trying to fix the hatch. Unless you’d rather stay in here with whatever’s out there.”

A wet, slithering sound scraped along the exterior. Both froze. Hardy’s sensors whirred, scanning for biometrics. Reggie’s breath fogged his visor as panic threatened to overwhelm him. The lights flickered. The airlock’s outer hatch creaked, as if something was testing it from the other side.

Reggie whimpered, “Can’t you go any faster?”

Hardy glanced at him, optics narrowing. “Not unless you want my fist to go through the hull.”

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The detective, a tall woman with a permanent frown etched into her brow, tapped the tape recorder with a long, red fingernail. “So you want to change your statement?” she asked. 

He nodded, voice hoarse. “I didn’t steal anything. I was scared. They said if I didn’t sign, I wouldn’t see my daughter again.”

Outside, the rain hammered the city, washing neon colors into the gutters. His lawyer, a young man with tired eyes, leaned forward. “Did anyone threaten you?”

He hesitated. “They said… things. About what happens to people like me in jail. I just wanted to go home.”

The detective’s frown deepened, but she clicked off the recorder. “We’ll look into it.”

Later, back in his cell, he stared at the chipped paint, wondering if anyone would believe him now. In the distance, a siren wailed. He whispered his daughter’s name like a prayer, hoping the truth might find its way out of these walls. But the truth, he realized, was another prisoner—waiting for someone to set it free.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The morning sun barely filtered through the barred window of his holding cell as Officer Tolland handed him a dry sandwich and a cup of water. “You ready to talk?” the officer asked, his voice low, almost sympathetic.

“I need to speak with someone,” he said, voice trembling. “I didn’t do what they said. They made me say it.”

Later, in the echoing interrogation room, his new statement was recorded. He described the threats, the sleepless hours, the flickering fluorescent lights. He spoke of the promise they’d made: confess, and you’ll go home. But the truth gnawed at him, and in that gnawing he found a sliver of hope.

Outside, the city moved on, indifferent. His confession, once a certainty, now flickered in the paperwork—a smudge, a question. The detectives exchanged glances. The wheels of justice—slow, grinding—began to turn in a new direction, one that might, just might, lead to the truth.

“I only said what they wanted because I was so tired, and they wouldn’t let me call anyone,” he said, his eyes darting to the back, where his mother sat gripping her purse. “None of it was true.”

The prosecutor scowled, shuffling papers. His defense attorney whispered encouragement. He described the hours, the threats, the fear. Each word peeled away the certainty of his guilt.

When he finished, a hush lingered. The judge regarded him, then the officers. Outside, rain tapped the windows. He wondered if he’d ever be believed, if justice had already slipped away in the night. He recanted, but the confession—a shadow—still clung to him, refusing to dissolve.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. By then, a storm had swept through the city, uprooting trees and flooding the basement of the aging police station. As water crept along the linoleum, he stared at his reflection in the puddle, fractured by the flickering overhead light. He remembered the detective’s voice, soft as velvet, promising safety if he just agreed to the story they offered. But now, as thunder rattled the barred window, clarity struck. In the hush that followed, the captain nodded, scribbling a note. Outside, the city began to drain and the sun pressed against the clouds. He hoped, as the light pooled on the floor, that truth could survive the flood. His future, uncertain and shimmering, waited for the storm to pass.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man’s shoes glint with the same hunger as his eyes. He turns, surveying the row of battered sedans and the corner deli like a hawk among sparrows. “You must be Jonah,” he replies, accent velvet and sharp. “You said to make an entrance.”

Jonah’s smile falters. He hadn’t meant it literally. He tugs his thrift-store jacket tighter, feeling the sting of oil under his nails. The Ferrari’s door swings closed with a sigh, and the tall man produces a small, battered violin case.

“Is that—” Jonah starts, but the man is already approaching, case in hand. He sets it atop the Ferrari’s hood, ignoring the stunned stares from passing teens. The latches click. Inside, not a violin: but a nest of wires and blinking lights.

Jonah swallows, remembering why he called. “Can you do it?”

The man smiles, teeth like piano keys. “For this city? Anything.”

Jonah hesitates, thinking of the envelope in his pocket, the instructions scrawled in invisible ink. He slides in, heart pounding. As the doors seal, the Ferrari’s engine hums—a sound like a secret being told.

One night, I find a new page. The ink is still wet. It reads, "Thank you for listening." I look up, heart pounding. The room across the hall is dark, but I sense him there, not just as a story, but as a presence close as breath. I whisper, "You’re welcome," and begin to write.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man doesn’t smile, but his eyes flicker with amusement. He flips his keys into the air, catching them with a practiced snap. The setting sun gleams off the cherry-red paint, stinging Jonah’s eyes.

“Would you prefer a bicycle?” the man replies, his accent a blend of continents.

Jonah shrugs, trying not to stare. “Just seems a bit much for a place like this.”

The man surveys the cracked pavement, the faded sign above the pawn shop. “Appearances are everything. Even here.” He nods toward the trunk, which clicks open with a sigh. Jonah’s heart skips. He wasn’t told there’d be a trunk involved.

The man lifts out a battered violin case, incongruous next to the Ferrari’s pristine interior. He hands it to Jonah, who’s surprised by its lightness.

“Be careful,” the man whispers. “Sometimes, what’s inside is louder than the car.”

As the Ferrari roars away, Jonah holds the violin case, feeling the weight of a secret humming beneath his fingers. Across the street, shadowed figures begin to move, drawn by the subtle symphony that has only just begun.

“Only the best for a subtle job,” the man replies. He snaps his fingers; the car’s butterfly doors rise, and a faint wisp of fog escapes from within. Jonah hesitates but steps closer, peering inside. The interior pulses with a gentle blue glow, and in the passenger seat sits a plush rabbit, its button eyes watching solemnly.

The man leans in. “You brought the envelope?”

Jonah nods, producing a thick manila envelope from his jacket. Their hands meet briefly as they exchange items—the rabbit for the envelope. The man cradles the envelope like a relic, while Jonah, holding the rabbit, feels a sudden, inexplicable weight in his arms. The wind picks up, swirling with scents of ozone and burnt sugar. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. But last night, at exactly 3:17 a.m., I scrolled past a video that was different. The whale—an old, barnacled blue—looked straight into the lens. I swear, its left eye blinked twice, then the video stuttered. Suddenly, the screen went black except for a line of text: "We know you see us."

I thought it was a joke, some viral marketing. But then the DMs started flooding in. Random strings of whale emojis, GPS coordinates, and cryptic messages like “Surface soon.”

Curiosity got the better of me. I typed the coordinates into Google Maps. They pointed to a stretch of ocean off the coast of Iceland. I booked the next flight, not telling anyone.

When I reached the shoreline, a dense fog rolled in. My phone vibrated. Another message: “Dive.”

Standing on the rocky edge, I hesitated, then stepped forward, letting the chill swallow me. As I sank, a chorus of whale songs echoed through the water. Somewhere in the gloom, I glimpsed an eye, warm and wise. It blinked twice.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. Last week, though, one video changed everything. Someone had managed to film a pod of whales forming perfect circles with their bodies, then, in unison, they began to spiral downward into the deep blue. The camera followed, bubbles streaming upward. Suddenly, the footage glitched—static, then a frame of a handwritten note: “They remember.”

I laughed, assumed it was a prank. But over the next few days, my feed filled with more cryptic notes. “You should listen.” “They’re not alone.” “The song is for you.”

I started hearing whale songs when my phone was off. Once, late at night, I awoke to the sound of splashing outside. I live nowhere near the ocean. Still, I opened the window. In the streetlight’s glow, a slick, grey shadow slid across the pavement, singing softly. My heart pounded. I grabbed my phone, but the camera wouldn’t focus.

Now, every night, I dream in blue, drifting, spiraling, singing. The whales are calling. And I think, soon, I’ll answer.

It’s become a ritual: every morning, I wake up, brush my teeth, and scroll, letting the slow, massive energy of the whales soak into my bones. But one day, I caught a live stream. A scientist in Antarctica, bundled up in red, was narrating as a pod of orcas skirted the edge of an ice shelf. Suddenly, the camera tumbled—someone shouting, snow flying—and the feed cut out. 

For weeks, nothing. I messaged the account; no response. Then, a DM: "Don’t look for us." The next video uploaded was just a dark, underwater blur, a low vibration rumbling through my speakers. It felt like a warning, or a welcome. Now, sometimes, I dream of ice and black water, of something huge moving beneath me, singing in a language older than the internet. I still scroll every morning, but now I wonder what I’m really watching, and if something is watching back.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. Not in the way people imagine, with the crackle of thunder in my hands or armies at my beck and call, but in the old sense—the kind of power that whispers in the ear of the wind, that coaxes seeds to sprout beneath winter’s snow. My grandmother taught me the songs to wake the bees and the dances to keep the crows from the corn. I watched the seasons turn at my fingertips. But the world changed, and so did I. Concrete choked the fields, and the air forgot how to listen. Still, sometimes, when I hum to myself in the alley behind my apartment, a dandelion pushes through the cracks, and the sparrows linger just a moment longer on the wires. I am quieter now, but the old power lingers, gentle as a sigh, stubborn as hope.

But power is a peculiar thing, fleeting as a shadow at dusk. The last time I tried to call the city to me, it remained silent, indifferent. I stood alone on the empty street, the world spinning on, my voice swallowed by the roar of engines. Still, sometimes, in the hush before dawn, I sense the city remembering me, a ghost in the circuitry, a whisper in the wires.

Now, I stand barefoot in the fields, coaxing seedlings with soft songs, and my hands are gentle; my heart, at last, is strong.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The echo rang through the cramped escape pod, mingling with the synthetic groans of the hull. Reggie’s eyes darted to the flickering oxygen readout, then to the single porthole, where a blue-green nebula spun lazily. Hardy’s fist stilled, and he glared at the bulkhead as if it had insulted him personally.

“I told you to check the fuel cells,” Hardy growled, voice metallic and deep, a side effect of the replacement larynx.

Reggie’s mouth opened, then closed. He shrank against the wall, clutching the emergency beacon as though it could save them merely by proximity. “I—I thought you checked them.”

Hardy’s eyes flashed. “We’ve got two hours of air. Maybe less.”

A sudden, high-pitched chirp interrupted, emanating from the beacon. Reggie stared in disbelief as a holographic face flickered to life above the device. It winked. “Greetings, escapees. Please state your favorite color to initiate rescue.”

Hardy groaned. Reggie licked his lips. “Cerulean?”

The hologram frowned. “Incorrect. You have one attempt remaining.”

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The clang reverberated through the submarine, setting off a chorus of squeaking valves and rattling pipes. Somewhere above, brine trickled through a hairline fracture, painting the steel with a trembling line of salt.

“Just keep it together, Reg,” Hardy barked, frustration boiling over. His mechanical arm hissed as he flexed it, sparks flying from the knuckles. “If I can’t get the hatch loose, we’re done for.”

Reggie’s teeth chattered. “We shouldn’t have taken this job, Hardy. We’re not treasure hunters, we’re janitors!”

Hardy snorted. “Janitors don’t get hazard pay.” He pounded the bulkhead again. The metal groaned, but then, with a shriek, the panel buckled inward, revealing a dark, waterlogged tunnel. A faint golden glow pulsed at its far end, illuminating barnacle-encrusted machinery and something that looked suspiciously like a crown.

Hardy grinned. “Looks like we just got promoted.”

Reggie whimpered, but followed Hardy into the unknown, the clang of the metal fist echoing behind them like a warning bell.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The sound was thunderous in the silent, pitch-black corridor, vibrating through Reggie’s bones. It was supposed to be abandoned—Hardy had sworn the station’s manifest was clear for another five months. Yet here they were, trapped between two sealed airlocks, alarms blaring somewhere distant, and the faintest hint of movement in the shadows.

"You hear that?" Hardy’s voice came out low, mechanical, the synth-vocoder distorting his words.

Reggie nodded, unable to muster a reply. He clutched the data core tighter, knuckles white, as the footsteps grew louder. A blue light flickered, illuminating the insignia of the security droids they’d hoped to avoid.

"Plan B?" Reggie whispered.

Hardy grinned, teeth flashing beneath the metal plates of his jaw. "Run."

As the bulkhead slid open, Hardy surged forward, metal fist raised, while Reggie darted after him, heart hammering. The data core pulsed in his arms—whatever secrets it held, they were about to be paid for in sweat, steel, and maybe something more.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The noise seemed to mock their predicament, echoing back in the cramped maintenance shaft like laughter from some unseen specter.

“Will you quit it?” Reggie hissed, voice trembling. “You’re going to bring the whole hive down on us!”

Hardy shrugged, the servos in his shoulder whining. “If I don’t get us out, the drones will find us anyway.” He hammered again, the metal ringing out like a dinner bell for disaster.

Above, dust drifted from the seams. Below, the shaft vibrated with the unmistakable hum of approaching wings. Reggie’s breath caught. “I told you this was a bad idea.”

Hardy’s eyes glinted—a flash of stubborn courage, or madness. “It’s a worse idea to stay put.”

Suddenly, the bulkhead groaned and swung inward, revealing a tunnel lined with bioluminescent fungus and the faint outline of an escape pod. Hardy grinned. “After you, Reg.”

Reggie swallowed his fear and ducked inside, the sound of Hardy’s metal fist still echoing in his ears.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The air tasted of ozone and burnt sugar, a leftover trace from the portal. She gripped the back of a chair, knuckles whitening, as his shadow flickered in the periphery of the shattered skylight. 

“Stay back,” she managed, voice too thin to be convincing. Her mind reeled, cataloguing the objects in the room: a broken lamp, a porcelain cat, the heavy velvet curtain. Nothing that could stop a man who fell from the sky.

His boots scraped across the glass, slow and deliberate. He didn’t speak. She edged toward the window, heartbeat hammering in her ears. If she could just make it outside—

He leapt. She hurled the porcelain cat, missing by a foot. He snatched it from the air, examining it with a surgeon’s calm before setting it gently on the tabletop. His eyes, inhumanly bright, met hers. “You’re braver than I expected,” he said softly, and the next instant, he vanished, leaving only the faint echo of his words and the unsettling certainty that he’d be back.

From the gloom, he rose, impossibly tall, his outline flickering as though caught between frames of an old film. His voice was wrong, too loud for the small space. "You can’t hide, Eliza."

She braced herself, searching for something—anything—to defend against what he had become. The lamp on the side table, the heavy glass ashtray, the letter opener glinting under a pale shaft of moonlight. She weighed her options, but nothing felt real anymore.

For that brief second, she saw the world as it was—a doorway, open and waiting. Without thinking, she leapt through, the echo of his laughter chasing her into the unknown.

The air was thick with the musk of old velvet and the faintest whiff of gunpowder. Her bare soles stuck to the parquet as she shuffled backwards, the rhythmic tick of the grandfather clock a metronome for her panic. Through the tangle of chair legs she glimpsed a gloved hand—long, elegant fingers splayed, palm pressed to the floor as if testing its reality. Then, a voice, smooth as oil: "I see you’ve redecorated, Mina."

She stifled a gasp. That voice belonged to no one living. She snatched up a candlestick, gripping it tight, and forced herself to speak, "Stay back. You’re not supposed to be here."

He rose, impossibly tall, impossibly unchanged, the years sliding from his shoulders like rain. His eyes were not the color she remembered. "No one’s supposed to be here," he said, stepping into the candlelight, casting monstrous shadows on the walls. "But here we are."

All at once, the clock stopped. The night pressed in, and the chase began anew.

"It’s not opening," Hardy growled, his voice echoing through the steel tube. "Something’s jammed."

Hardy turned, eyes glinting. "When those doors open, you run. I’ll hold it off as long as I can. Just get to the escape pod."

Reggie nodded, his terror replaced by cold resolve. For the first time, he realized just how heavy the silence was—and how loud the creature’s hunger had become.

The old gymnasium echoed with the heavy silence that follows catastrophe. She scanned the collapsed ceiling tiles and the cloud of dust motes swirling in the moonlight. There, by the far wall, a hand twitched beneath a mound of debris. She bit her lip, torn between flight and the curious ache of responsibility. The last time she’d seen him, he wore a smile that promised trouble. Now, his silhouette was monstrous, limbs askew, breath rattling. She slid behind the nearest chair, heart thumping, and called out, "Are you hurt?" No answer—just a low, guttural moan that was more beast than man. She inched away, feet barely touching the ground. The gym door loomed behind her, salvation or trap, she couldn’t decide. With one last look at the writhing shape, she tightened her jaw and ran, the sound of splintering wood chasing her into the night, where the world seemed suddenly stranger and more dangerous than she had ever imagined.

instance_metrics.response: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The air smelled of ozone, sharp and electric, as if lightning had struck inside the room. She pressed a shaking hand to her chest, feeling her heart thud against her ribs. The silence was complete except for the faint, rhythmic ticking of her wristwatch. Slowly, she circled around the chairs, her gaze fixed on the spot where the shadows seemed to ripple. Then, impossibly, a boot emerged—floating a few inches above the ground, followed by the rest of him, translucent and shimmering. He hovered in the air, his face flickering between familiar and utterly unknown. "You shouldn’t have followed me," his voice echoed, layered and doubled. She swallowed, standing her ground. "You left me no choice," she replied, her voice steadier than she felt. As he reached out a hand, the room seemed to bend, the walls curving inward. She hesitated, then stepped forward, chairs forgotten, drawn by the possibility that there were answers in the impossible, and perhaps, a way home.

In the Hudson?”  “In the swimming lake.”  

Liam’s voice echoed under the bridge as he pointed to the water. “They say at midnight, the fish light up.”

Anna squinted at the moonlit ripples, doubting. “That’s just a story.”

But when the clock struck twelve, the surface shimmered. Flecks of emerald and sapphire danced beneath, swirling with the current. Anna gasped as a giant carp, scales aglow, surfaced before them. Around its neck: a locket, tarnished but unmistakable. The locket her grandmother lost fifty years ago.

Liam reached out, but the carp dove, trailing luminescence. Anna plunged in after it, the cold biting her skin, the world growing silent and green. Underwater, time stilled. She followed the fish through a tunnel of light, emerging in a sunlit glade where a younger version of her grandmother waited, locket in hand.

"You found me," her grandmother whispered.

Anna awoke on the shore, clutching the locket, dawn breaking over the Hudson. Liam smiled knowingly. “Told you so.”
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

instance_metrics.response:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

That’s how the argument started, anyway. By dawn, the two of them had built a raft out of driftwood and old bicycle tires, determined to find the answer. They paddled silently, mist curling on the water, past the place where the blue herons nested, toward the far side where the trees leaned in like nosy neighbors.

Halfway across, the water turned cold. Too cold. The raft rocked. Something brushed against their feet—a shiver, a shadow, the memory of a drowned town beneath the lake. The silence grew heavy.

“Last chance to turn back,” she whispered.

But he shook his head, eyes fixed on the impossible shimmer ahead. When they reached it, the water parted, revealing the spire of an old church, bell still hanging, echoing with a sound only they could hear. They knew, then, that some stories were true, and some lakes held more than fish.

They never spoke about the Hudson again.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

instance_metrics.response:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Nobody believed Alex, least of all his sister, but on the sticky summer night when the moon was high, they crept out to the water’s edge. The lake was still, glassy, as if waiting.

Alex waded in first, his toes sinking into cool silt. He reached the middle, where the old willow’s reflection shivered. “Now,” he whispered.

Something moved: a swirl of color, a glint of scales. A fish, but not like any fish she’d seen—its eyes glowed silver, and it wore a tiny crown of river grass. It circled Alex, then darted away, beckoning.

He followed, disappearing into the darkness. She called out, heart pounding, but no answer came—only the faint, far-off sound of laughter and splashes. When she finally returned home, a small fish-scale crown lay on her pillow, damp and glimmering.

No one ever swam in the lake again, but some nights, when the wind was right, she heard Alex’s laughter, rippling across the water.

instance_metrics.response:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

It was the kind of summer twilight when the air buzzed with insects and secrets. Mia clutched her flashlight as she followed Jamie to the dock, the boards creaking beneath their feet. He’d sworn he saw something strange—glinting, twisting beneath the water’s skin.

They waited, silent, the world shrinking to the hush of cattails and the distant call of a loon. Then, with a sudden splash, a shape breached the surface: a pale, translucent eel, shimmering with impossible colors. It spiraled upward, and for a moment, Mia thought she saw a face—gentle, ancient, smiling.

Jamie reached out, trembling. The eel coiled around his fingers, cool and electric. He gasped, and light flickered along his arm, as if the creature was sharing a secret language of light.

Then, as quickly as it appeared, the eel slipped away, leaving only ripples. Mia and Jamie stared at each other, hearts pounding. They never spoke of it again, but every summer, they returned to the swimming lake, just in case.

instance_metrics.response:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The distinction seemed trivial, but to Maribel, it was everything. The Hudson was for barges and secrets, the swimming lake for laughter and splinters from the old dock. Yet tonight, as she slipped into the inky waters beneath a sky spattered with stars, something felt uncanny. The water was colder, thicker, and as she swam toward the center, she noticed the current—there shouldn’t be a current.

A glimmer below, like city lights viewed through fog, drew her deeper. She dove, lungs burning, and found herself brushing past broken bottles, river grass, and—impossibly—a subway token. When she surfaced, the dock was gone. Instead, skyscrapers loomed, their windows glowing gold, and the hum of distant traffic echoed off the water.

She was in the Hudson, somehow. The swimming lake had bled into the river’s dream, and she, Maribel of both laughter and secrets, floated between worlds, the water holding her gently as she chose which shore to swim toward.

instance_metrics.response: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. With trembling fingers, he drew the bundle out from under the floorboards, careful not to let the ancient dust settle on the delicate mechanisms. The cloth was moth-eaten and frayed, but inside lay the automaton heart his grandfather had built a century ago—an artifact forbidden by the Council, rumored to contain memories and voices of the past. He cradled it close, listening to the faint clicking within. Outside, the hounds bayed, the metallic scent of ozone thickening as the air shifted. He knew time was short. With a swift motion, he unwrapped the gears, exposing the intricate clockwork. He whispered the words passed down through his family, and the gears began to move. The automaton’s eye flickered open, illuminating the darkness beneath the floor. The hounds paused, uncertain. He clutched the heart, praying the old stories were true: that the machine would open a door not just to escape, but to a world where memory and hope were not outlawed. As the floorboards trembled, he realized the journey had only begun.

instance_metrics.response: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. With a furtive glance over his shoulder, he pulled the bundle free, heart hammering in his chest. He remembered his grandmother’s whispered warnings: "Never wind it, unless you’re ready for the consequences." But the council’s men were coming, their heavy boots echoing above. Desperation outweighed caution. He twisted the tiny silver key. The bird shuddered, then burst into song. Instead of music, the air shimmered and a swirling portal opened in the wall. The ground shook. He clutched the bird and leapt through, leaving the cellar—and his old life—far behind. On the other side, the world was awash in clockwork cities and mechanical trees, the sky alive with gears and cogs. The bird fluttered from his hands, calling others of its kind. He realized his journey had only just begun, in a land where time itself could be wound and unwound at will.

The marionette bowed, gesturing for him to join. As he stepped forward, his own limbs felt lighter, guided by unseen threads. The marionette smiled. Together, they danced, the music swelling from nowhere and everywhere, and as the last note faded, he wondered if he’d ever find his way back to the world above.

He knelt, whispering thanks, and crawled forward, emerging in a forgotten grove behind the old house. The automaton sat by his side, silent now, but he knew the way home was open again.

He followed, discovering a hidden letter—written in his mother’s hand, addressed to him. Tears pricked his eyes as he unfolded it. Sometimes, he realized, you have to dig through the gears of the past to find the words you need most in the present.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The echo of his descent still vibrated through the empty theatre, a low thrum that seemed to pulse under her skin. She counted the rows, measuring the distance to the exit, but the velvet darkness pressed in, making space itself unreliable. Her breath hitched. Was that a shadow, moving? She gripped the back of a chair, knuckles pale. 

"Stay away," she managed, her voice a brittle whisper. The air shifted; a cold draft brushed against her ankle. She risked a glance over the seats, only to see his silhouette rise, impossibly tall, limbs contorting as if joints had forgotten their purpose. 

"You shouldn’t have come back," he rasped, voice leaking from a mouth she couldn’t see. 

She weighed her options: run for the stage door, or try to lose him in the maze of seats. The chairs, once familiar, now seemed like obstacles in a nightmare. She forced herself to move, weaving between them, heart hammering. But with every step she took, his footsteps echoed, closer and closer, chasing her through the darkness she thought she’d left behind.

instance_metrics.response:
She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The window was still rattling from the impact, shards of moonlight slicing across the floor. She pressed her palm against the cool wood of the nearest chair, focusing on the sensation to ground herself. 

Then she heard it: a slow, deliberate exhale, like air escaping from a punctured tire. The creature—no, the man—shifted in the darkness, his silhouette monstrous and hunched. She remembered the stories, how he’d been seen only in glimpses, always at the edge of vision. 

He moved again, a slithering sound as he dragged himself upright. Her mind raced, searching for something to throw, some way to distract him. She grabbed a heavy book from the table and hurled it, aiming for the far corner. The noise exploded in the quiet, and for a heartbeat, everything hung suspended. 

She ran. Past the chairs, past the shadow, into the cold night, never daring to look back. The only thing she took with her was the certainty that she’d never forget the sound of his landing—or the fear that it might not be the last time she heard it.

He moved oddly, as if learning how to use his body for the first time, limbs bending at strange angles. His eyes—she could see them now—glowed with a pale, unnatural light. "You shouldn't have looked," he whispered, voice echoing from everywhere and nowhere.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The old parlor was shrouded in a sickly, amber glow; dust motes hovered, disturbed by the sudden violence. She steadied herself, eyes darting to the mantle where the heavy clock ticked in slow, uneven beats. 

A gentle scraping made her stomach clench. He was close, closer than she’d thought. She shuffled backward, the chairs scraping in protest. He stepped into the light, but his features were wrong—blurred, as if painted in water that hadn’t dried. His gaze fixed on her, unblinking. 

“I told you not to come back,” he said, voice thick with something she couldn’t name. She wanted to scream or run, but her legs wobbled. The room seemed to shrink around her, the air thick with secrets and regret. She drew a breath and steeled herself. Whatever he was, whatever she had done, she had to face it—if only to escape the suffocating weight of her own terror.

The antique tea set on the table rattled, one porcelain cup spinning on its saucer as if the impact had sent a tremor through the room. She pressed her back against the velvet upholstery, scanning the shadows. There—between the grandfather clock and the faded oil painting—a faint shimmer, like oil on water, rippled in the air. She swallowed, remembering the warnings: don’t call his name, don’t meet his gaze, and above all, never be caught between mirrors after dark. But the only way out was through the hallway, its walls lined with glassy reflections. The shimmer grew, taking shape, limbs unfolding with a deliberate grace. “You said you wouldn’t return,” a voice whispered, echoing from everywhere and nowhere. Heart pounding, she hurled a chair into the hallway, shattering a mirror, shards skittering across the floor. The shimmer recoiled, fracturing into a dozen spectral figures. She ran, dodging the glass, the sound of her own pulse drowning out the chorus of voices that rose behind her—a warning she was already too late to heed.

Without a goodbye, Jasper slipped quietly through the back door, his duffel bag hanging loosely from his shoulder. The city was still sleeping, bathed in the bluish haze before dawn. He paused only once, glancing back at the crooked window where he and Mariel had spent endless nights dreaming of freedom. The silence pressed against his ears, heavier than any farewell. He left no letter, no trace but his absence. 

As the train rattled through the outskirts, Jasper pressed his forehead to the glass, the world blurring into a tapestry of gray and green. Regret nibbled at him, but he kept it buried beneath layers of determination. Somewhere, far from the weight of expectation, he would find his voice. Maybe one day he’d return, but for now, the only thing he carried was hope—and a memory of a love he couldn’t yet explain.

Without a goodbye, Mira stepped into the swirling fog, her silhouette dissolving into the night as if she were never there at all. The house behind her remained lit, laughter echoing from inside, but she felt like a ghost haunting her own life. Each footstep away was an unspoken apology, a confession folded into the darkness. 

She walked until the city lights faded, until only the hush of distant waves accompanied her. Mira’s heart thudded with every memory she left behind: the warmth of a shared mug, the gentle touch at sunrise, the plans etched into kitchen steam. Yet she kept moving. Somewhere beyond the fog, perhaps, she would find herself—if not forgiven, at least free.

Without a goodbye, the blue parakeet soared from the open window, leaving the cage door swinging gently in the morning breeze. Lena stared at the empty perch, her heart pounding with a mix of disbelief and awe. For years, she’d whispered secrets to her feathered companion, confiding dreams she dared not speak aloud. Now, the room felt impossibly large, the silence thick and restless.

Outside, a flash of turquoise darted above the rooftops, vanishing into the sunlit sprawl. Lena pressed her hand to the pane, uncertain whether she mourned or celebrated the bird’s escape. She understood, though, that the urge to fly was not a betrayal, but a calling. In that moment, Lena promised herself that she, too, would one day find the courage to slip quietly past the boundaries that held her, chasing the horizon with or without a goodbye.

Without a goodbye, the carousel spun for the last time beneath the battered striped tent. Workers dismantled the horses and mirrors in silence, their faces grim with the knowledge that tomorrow, the fairground would be nothing but flattened grass and trampled dreams. Among them, a small boy watched, clutching a tarnished ticket stub in his fist.

He had waited every summer for the music and colored lights, for the brief magic that made him feel as if he belonged. But this year, the magic ended quietly, with no fanfare or farewell. As the truck rumbled away, the boy tucked the ticket into his pocket, vowing to remember the wonder that once lived there, even if it vanished without a goodbye.

instance_metrics.response: Without a goodbye, the clocks in the old observatory began ticking backward. Dr. Ilona Voss watched as midnight melted into dusk, as yesterday’s notes rewrote themselves on her desk. Shadows unspooled across the marble floor, carrying faint echoes of footsteps long departed. Ilona’s colleagues had warned her: never adjust the main dial alone. But curiosity, potent as gravity, pulled her hands to the brass mechanism. Now, with each reversed chime, she glimpsed fleeting fragments of all the farewells she’d never spoken—her mother’s soft lullaby, her brother’s last laugh, the mentor who vanished one stormy night. Time spun her gently through these silent partings, not to change them, but to see them clearly. When, at last, the clocks stilled, Ilona found herself alone in the observatory, heart brimming with unsaid words, and the understanding that sometimes, absence is the truest farewell.

instance_metrics.response: Are there children? The question echoed through the abandoned amusement park as the sun dipped below the horizon. Mara, flashlight trembling in her hand, pressed her ear to the rusted carousel. Silence. But then, faint giggles drifted from the shadows. With each step, the laughter grew, twining around her fear. She glimpsed movement—a blur of striped socks and tattered ribbons darting between the horses. "Come play," a voice whispered, ancient and ageless. Mara hesitated, heart pounding. She remembered the stories: the children who vanished here decades ago, never found. Now, the air shimmered, and dozens of small hands reached out from the spinning carousel, eyes wide and pleading. "Stay with us," they chorused. Mara stumbled back, desperate to flee, but the gates had vanished. Only the laughter remained, swirling in the twilight, as she realized she was no longer alone—and never would be again.

instance_metrics.response: Are there children? The question, scrawled in dusty chalk on the ancient oak's trunk, was the first thing Mila saw as she entered the clearing. The words pulsed with a strange energy, as if the tree itself was asking. Mila hesitated, clutching her basket of wildflowers. The forest had always been silent, save for the wind and the birds, but today, she heard soft footsteps—bare feet pattering on moss. Suddenly, a circle of children appeared, spectral and shimmering, surrounding the tree. Their eyes were bright, their faces serene. "We are here," they whispered in unison. Mila blinked, heart thudding. She tried to speak, but no words came. The children smiled, beckoning her forward. She stepped into the circle, and the forest changed: brighter, warmer, filled with laughter and song. The chalk words faded. Mila understood then—she had been invited, not warned. She joined hands with the children, and together they danced, forever part of the clearing's gentle magic.

instance_metrics.response: Are there children? The old woman’s voice quavered as she peered through the cracked window. The nurse hesitated, her hand hovering above the doorknob. "Not for a long time," she replied, but her words vanished into the hush of the twilight. Yet, as darkness crept across the hallway, faint patters echoed from the attic above—laughter, quick footsteps, a lullaby hummed in a voice too sweet to belong to anyone living. Each night, the sounds grew bolder, and the old woman waited, clutching a faded photograph of three children, their faces half-remembered. On the seventh night, the door creaked open. The room filled with the scent of wildflowers and the gentle touch of invisible hands. The old woman smiled, tears tracing her cheeks. "Yes," she whispered, "there are children." And with that, she closed her eyes, surrendering to the laughter that carried her home.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. Once, I could raise mountains with my laughter and command the tides with a single sigh. But after centuries spent shaping the world to my whim, I grew weary of my own echo in the void. So I folded myself into human skin, a patchwork of borrowed memories and fragile bones. Now, I walk among you, unnoticed, savoring the thunder of a heartbeat and the miracle of hunger. My hands are soft, no longer talons or lightning; my voice trembles when I speak. But in quiet moments, when the wind tastes of storms and the shadows lengthen, I remember. And for a heartbeat, the world remembers me too.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. My name was once whispered in the corridors of the constellations, feared by kings and courted by gods. But I traded my might for a single, impossible wish: to watch a cherry blossom fall in spring, unburdened by the weight of eternity. Now, as I sit beneath this tree, petals drifting down like silent snow, I wonder if my bargain was foolish or wise. For though my hands tremble and my heart aches with mortality, the beauty of this moment pierces me deeper than any victory or conquest ever could.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. In those days, I could stride across the burning sands without leaving a trace, my cloak shimmering with the heat of a thousand suns. Empires rose and fell at my command, and rivers changed course to avoid my wrath. Yet, it was a single, gentle touch that undid me—a child's hand reaching for mine, not out of fear, but trust. In that instant, the world shifted. My power, vast as it was, seemed hollow against the soft warmth of a small palm. I learned then that the greatest force is not dominion, but connection, and so I let my power fade, choosing love over legend.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. I once turned the gears of fate, spinning lives into chaos or harmony as I pleased. My eyes saw through the fabric of reality, and my words bent time to my will. But when I peered too closely at the threads I wove, I saw my own reflection—lonely, desperate, yearning for a single true friend. So I unraveled my own tapestry, letting my powers slip away, and stepped out into the world as an ordinary soul. Now, I search for connection, hoping someone will see the spark that lingers quietly within me.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. I could silence thunder with a glance and coax forgotten languages from the cracks in ancient stones. My shadow stretched from mountaintops to ocean trenches, and legends sprouted in my wake. But on the eve of the eclipse, I glimpsed a moth struggling against a windowpane and, for the first time, felt powerless to intervene. I opened the window and let it fly free, realizing that sometimes the greatest power lies not in control, but in letting go. Since then, I have walked quietly, learning the language of small mercies.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. But the moonlit forest, thick with the scent of wet earth and the soft, echoing hoots of distant owls, feels empty save for my own trembling footsteps. I press the photograph of her—a candid smile from last summer—against my chest, hoping its warmth can reach her wherever she is.

Ahead, the path splits into three. The search party’s lights flicker somewhere to the east, their voices muffled by mossy trunks. I know I should wait for them, but the silence tugs at my resolve. I listen for any sign: the snap of a twig, her soft humming. Instead, the wind carries a whisper. "Here."

Heart pounding, I choose the middle path, guided by hope or perhaps desperation. Each step is a silent plea to the universe. If others are searching, let our paths converge. If she is frightened, let her know I am coming. In this endless night, trust is the only map I possess, and so I walk on, believing that love can bridge the distance between us and bring her home.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. But as I sit in the empty kitchen, the ticking clock grows louder, each second a question. Did someone remember to check the old garden? Did they ask the neighbors about the midnight train?

I pour over her letters, searching for clues in looping handwriting. She always wrote in metaphors—never direct, always hinting at wild places and hidden dreams. I remember her saying, "If you ever lose me, follow the birds."

So, I rise and slip into the night, following the distant cooing of doves. The city is a labyrinth; every shadow could be her, every echo a memory. As dawn breaks, I spot a feather on the curb—blue, impossibly bright. I pick it up, hope blooming in my chest. Maybe someone else found a feather too, and maybe, together, we’re laying a trail leading her home. Trust is all I have now—trust in strangers, in omens, and in love’s stubborn persistence.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

But they both knew the difference. Hudson was a word that tasted of silt, of city secrets and forgotten shoes, while the swimming lake was all wild lilies and glassy mornings. The water in the lake always felt friendly, cool fingers twining around your ankles, a shy invitation. 

But when he disappeared last August, rumors drifted through the town like pollen. Some said he’d gone to the Hudson, chasing stories he’d whispered about: sunken boxcars and lost gold, the city’s old bones still rattling in the current. But I found his silver watch, caught on a cattail, right where the lilies bloom thickest.

Sometimes, at dusk, I wade in, feet stirring the sandy bottom, and listen. Not for answers, but for the hush of water remembering. The Hudson runs on, heavy and silent. But the lake holds its secrets lightly, like a promise just under the surface.

I remember the old stories: the lake and the river connected by a tunnel, carved out by hands desperate to escape, or to hide. We followed the shoreline, the water thick with fog. At the far end, reeds whispered secrets. I knelt, letting my fingers break the surface. It wasn’t the cold that made me shiver.

I looked out at the lake, sunlight glancing off the shallows. Somewhere beneath, secrets curled in the silt, peaceful as sleeping fish. "Some things stay buried," I said. "Some things float back up."

He stared at the water, then at me. "If it comes up, what do we do?"

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The sound echoed through the narrow corridor of the sunken research vessel, sending vibrations up Reggie’s spine. “It’s not going to help,” Reggie whispered, clutching the battered oxygen gauge close to his chest. The red needle quivered just below the critical line. 

Hardy growled, a metallic rasp accompanying the movement of his robotic arm. “I’m not sitting here waiting for that thing to come back,” he hissed. With each thud, the emergency lights flickered, casting grotesque shadows on the rusted walls.

From the far end of the corridor, a wet, slithering sound drew closer. Reggie’s breath caught. Hardy tensed, his cybernetic sensors whirring. “When I say run, you run,” Hardy said, never taking his eyes off the darkness beyond the bulkhead. “And don’t look back.”

As the bulkhead shuddered and bulged inward, Reggie realized it wasn’t just the pressure of the deep. Something outside wanted in, and Hardy’s fist might be the only thing standing between survival and oblivion.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The rhythm was uneven, desperate, echoing through the cramped lunar module. “You think they hear us?” Hardy grunted, not pausing his barrage.

Reggie’s voice was barely a whisper. “I think you’re making it worse. The hull isn’t built for—”

“–what, for me trying to get us rescued?” Hardy snapped. He slammed the bulkhead again, and a tiny puff of metallic dust drifted down. Outside, the stars shimmered, cold and indifferent.

Suddenly, a garbled transmission crackled through the comm. “Module Six, respond. Repeat, Module Six, are you—”

Hardy froze, fist midair. Reggie lunged for the radio, hope flickering in his terrified eyes. “We’re here! We’re alive!”

But what answered was not Mission Control, not any human voice at all. The static twisted into a guttural, alien growl. Hardy’s fist fell away from the wall as Reggie recoiled. The banging had woken something. Now, the real terror was just beginning.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

It was just after midnight when I glimpsed the lantern bobbing near the reeds. I thought it was a firefly at first, until I saw the silhouette carrying it—tall, thin, moving with a liquid grace that made the reeds part in silence. I watched from my bedroom window, breath fogging the glass.

This morning, I found footprints in the muddy shore, far too large to be mine or my brother’s. And something else: a ring of stones, arranged in a perfect circle, with a single black feather at the center.

Now, as my brother and I stood at the lake’s edge, he nudged me. “Let’s go see if it’s still there.”

I hesitated, recalling the strange figure. But curiosity won. We crept forward, together, into the shivering light of dawn, and the secret at the lake’s heart waited for us.

He fingers a chipped porcelain cup, eyes fixed on the swirling tea leaves at the bottom. “It was the clockmaker, you see. He promised he could turn back time, just for a night.”

I shift, uncertain whether to laugh or shiver. The old man’s gaze finds mine, luminous with something ancient. “He warned me there’d be a price. I paid it, of course. Anything for Marianne.”

A cold breeze snakes under the door. I glance at the clock on the mantle—its hands twitch, then spin backward. Shadows lengthen. At the window, a pale figure appears—her smile hauntingly familiar. Mr. Lamont stands, trembling with hope and dread. The air thickens, pressing in.

Outside, the church bells toll in reverse. “You mustn’t speak to her,” he whispers, voice cracking. But the longing in his eyes says otherwise. As the figure steps into the room, the world folds in on itself, and the price of love becomes terrifyingly clear.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. His voice is rough, aged by regrets and sleepless nights. "The old willow by the river still has her initials carved in the bark. Every spring, I bring fresh flowers, but the roots have grown wild, twisting around what’s left of the stone."

The room chills as dusk settles. I see the glint of a faded photograph in his hand—a girl laughing, arms outstretched. "They say the dead don’t linger, but sometimes, I hear her humming through the floorboards. Sometimes the scent of her perfume drifts in with the storm."

He looks at me, eyes watery. "If you see her, out there where the fog thickens, tell her I kept my promise. Tell her the lantern is still lit."

Thunder rumbles. Mr. Lamont’s silhouette seems smaller now, swallowed by memories too heavy for daylight. I nod, uncertain if I will ever find her, or if she ever truly left at all.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. The fire crackles, casting wild shadows across his gaunt face. And then... she came."

I lean in, heart pounding. "You saw her?"

He nods, eyes unfocused. "She stood in the water, hair tangled with lilies. But she wasn’t as I remembered. Her voice sounded like wind through hollow reeds, and her eyes—oh, her eyes were the color of the storm." He clutches the armrest. "She reached for me, but her touch burned cold. I wanted to run, but I couldn’t."

Lightning flashes, illuminating the room. Mr. Lamont shudders. "I think I brought back something that wears her face, but isn’t her at all."

I nod. Everyone in town knows them: the whistle that sounds only for the grieving, the conductor who never shows his face.

“I waited by the tracks, just as the clock struck twelve. I offered the conductor everything—my wedding ring, my favorite memory, even my voice. He asked for only one thing: a promise I could never break.” Mr. Lamont’s voice falters. “I swore I’d never look back. But when she stepped off that train... I couldn’t help myself.”

He takes a shaky breath. “Now the nights are colder. Sometimes I hear the train, far away, and I wonder if I kept my word, or if I lost her forever.”

The moonlight glimmered off ancient brass as he unraveled the fabric, revealing a contraption unlike any he’d seen—a pocket watch with an intricate maze of gears exposed, but no hands. He remembered his grandmother’s warning: never wind a clock unearthed under a new moon. Ignoring the tremor in his fingers, he twisted the crown. The world shuddered, trees flickering in and out of existence. Suddenly, he stood in a bustling Victorian street, unfamiliar faces whirling past. He clutched the watch to his chest, heart pounding. A voice whispered in his ear, 'You have borrowed time—return it, or remain lost.' Panicked, he tried to wind the watch back, but the gears stuck. The city faded, and he fell into darkness, the ticking echoing in his mind. When he awoke, all that remained was the cloth, empty and silent, and a lingering sense that time was no longer his to keep.

instance_metrics.response: When the pandemic hit, the governor issued stay-at-home orders. For most, this meant endless days indoors—Netflix, baking bread, video calls. But for Dr. Juniper Moss, it meant something entirely different. Her tiny apartment had always been a sanctuary, but now, the walls seemed to hum with energy. On the second week of lockdown, Juniper noticed a faint glow emanating from the cupboard under the sink. Cautiously, she opened it and found a door she’d never seen before. On the other side was a library larger than any city block, filled with books written in ancient, shifting scripts. Each day, as the world outside grew quieter, Juniper explored new corridors of knowledge. She met other travelers—some in pajamas, some in business suits—who’d found their way to the library from distant corners of the globe. It was a place born of collective longing and solitude, where knowledge and camaraderie grew in secret. When the orders finally lifted, Juniper returned to the world changed, carrying stories no pandemic could ever silence.

instance_metrics.response: When the pandemic hit, the governor issued stay-at-home orders. The world outside faded to a memory of traffic and laughter; inside, the air thickened with apprehension. On the third day, I noticed that my cat, Mercury, had begun to talk. At first, I thought it was the side effect of too many sleepless nights, but he addressed me clearly: "You should check the attic." I had never been to the attic. The hatch was stuck, but Mercury—now suddenly opposable-thumbed—helped me pry it open. Inside, dust motes danced in the sunlight, and a small, ancient radio awaited us in the corner. "It’s time," Mercury said. We tuned in, and the broadcast began: not news, but a story about a world where nothing changed, where people kept rushing, never stopping. We listened, hour after hour, learning about a place where connection was an afterthought. When the stay-at-home orders ended, I found myself slower, gentler, and Mercury never spoke again—but every time I glance at him, his eyes gleam with shared understanding.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. “But the cost was never just mine to bear.”

The candle’s flicker throws monstrous shadows on the peeling wallpaper. I clutch the photograph of my sister, her smile forever frozen in a summer that feels centuries away. Mr. Lamont’s eyes glisten with regret—or is it terror?

He clears his throat. “You must understand, when you asked me to help, you opened a door. She isn’t the same. None of them are.”

I press, desperate. “But she’s alive?”

He shakes his head. “Not alive. Not dead. She’ll come tonight, but you must not look at her face.”

The clock chimes midnight. The temperature drops, breath frosting the air. A soft knock at the door. My heart thunders.

“I’m sorry,” Mr. Lamont whispers. “I should never have taught you the words.”

The door swings open. There stands my sister, eyes black as the starless sky, voice like wind through broken glass. “You called me. Now you must come with me.”

I realize, too late, that some wishes can never be taken back.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again.

He leans forward on his cane, eyes fixed on the cracked linoleum floor. “They say time heals all wounds, but they never met the river.”

I shift uneasily, glancing out the rain-streaked window toward the swollen banks below the house. The room smells of old tobacco and regret.

“You think you can bargain with it?” His voice is brittle. “That you can give up a piece of yourself and get her laughter back, her warmth?”

I nod, guilt gnawing at me. The river took her, but I’d heard the stories. I’d come to Mr. Lamont—keeper of secrets, the last to speak the river’s language.

He slowly lifts his head, eyes clouded. “Midnight. Bring what you cherish most. But listen: she won’t remember you. You may not recognize her either.”

Thunder cracks. I clutch the locket she gave me on our last birthday, the metal cold against my palm. Outside, the river murmurs, promising miracles with a price I cannot yet understand.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again.

His voice is almost a whisper, brittle as old paper. “You don’t understand what you’re asking. Some doors, once opened, never close.”

I sit rigid, hands clenched in my lap. The ache in my chest is sharp, relentless. “I have nothing left to lose.”

He sighs, tapping a yellowed envelope against his knee. “You think grief is a pit. But it’s a labyrinth. Every turn leads you further from the light.”

I reach for the envelope, desperate. He pulls it away. “If you read what’s inside, you can never return. She might come back, but so will the shadow that follows her.”

The air thickens. I nod, ready to risk everything for a chance—a fleeting chance—to see her again. Mr. Lamont relents, sliding the envelope across the table. My trembling fingers break the seal, and as I begin to read, the world blurs, and the true cost of longing reveals itself.

He studies the swirling tea leaves in his chipped porcelain cup, then finally looks up, his gaze oddly luminous. "You know, sometimes the universe listens. But it doesn’t always answer kindly."

A shudder passes through me as the air thickens, the lights flickering overhead. Outside, a dog howls, its cry echoing through the empty street. Mr. Lamont’s voice drops to a whisper. These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She’d lined them up each night, careful to arrange their soft, worn bodies in a parade across her bed: the bear with matted velvet fur, the fox missing one shiny black eye, the rabbit whose ear drooped from too many midnight confessions. When she was five, they listened. When she was seven, they guarded her dreams. At ten, they watched her tears, absorbing silent secrets into their stuffing. 

Now, at twenty-seven, she opened the battered trunk beneath her childhood window. The air was thick with dust and memory. She pressed her face into the old bear and felt the years collapse into a single heartbeat. It hurt, this love—this ache for something that would never answer, never return the careful attention. But as she sat, surrounded by their muffled silence, she realized she’d never stopped loving things that couldn’t love her back. Old friends, old places, old dreams: they all lived on in the quiet, stitched seams of her heart. She smiled, set the bear on her lap, and began to tell it everything she never could say aloud.

instance_metrics.response:
These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She remembered the way she pressed her tiny hands into their plush sides, whispering secrets into buttoned ears. One by one, she’d patched their rips with thread and hope, and lined them up for tea parties where only she drank the imaginary tea. 

When she grew older, she gave them names she could never pronounce twice the same way. She built them houses from shoeboxes and watched them tumble down with every accidental kick. Still, she rebuilt, undeterred. The toys’ blank stares were both comfort and challenge: she poured her heart into their silence, learning that love sometimes meant caring for what cannot reply. 

Years later, as she packed for college, her mother suggested leaving them behind. But she tucked the smallest rabbit into her suitcase, a secret talisman of how she’d learned to love without expectation. That night, in her new room, she placed it by her pillow—a silent witness that love, once given, lingers on even in the quietest corners.

instance_metrics.response:
These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She’d built entire kingdoms for them, whispered to them her hopes and apologies, believing the plush menagerie could understand. There was the lion with a fraying mane, the penguin whose beak was patched with glue, and her favorite, a faded dinosaur with a crooked smile. 

When her father left, she pressed each animal close, seeking comfort in their unchanging presence. The world grew complicated outside her bedroom door, but inside, her silent companions waited. She learned to forgive them for their stillness, to cherish the way they listened without answers. 

Years later, moving boxes lined her dorm room, and she hesitated over the battered dinosaur. It could not offer her advice, nor dry her tears, but she tucked it on her pillow anyway—a small, stubborn reminder that loving without expectation had always made her braver than she realized.

Without a goodbye, the world turned slightly askew for Mira. She woke to a sky that shimmered with a violet haze, and the familiar hum of the city had been replaced by a curious silence. Her apartment, usually brimming with the scent of coffee and the echo of laughter, felt hollow, emptied of all but shadows. She found her partner’s favorite mug on the table, a scarf draped over the chair, but no note, no message – nothing but the lingering warmth of a recently used pillow.

Days blurred. At night, Mira traced constellations on the ceiling, searching for messages in the patterns. She wandered the city, following forgotten paths, asking strangers if they’d seen someone with a smile like dawn. Nobody had. Time grew thin. Then, one evening, a paper crane appeared on her windowsill, folded from a map of the city. Inside, a single line: “Some journeys have no return, but perhaps a new beginning.”

Mira smiled, not with understanding, but with acceptance. She folded her own crane, set it free on the breeze, and stepped out into the soft, violet dusk, ready to greet the world without a goodbye.

Without a goodbye, the clocks in the old train station stopped. It was as if time itself refused to continue, caught in the absence of a final word. Every morning, the stationmaster, Mr. Fenwick, polished the brass handles and swept the marble floors, waiting for the echo of a footstep that never returned. Commuters came and went, but the 4:17 departure remained eternally delayed, its platform dusted with petals from forgotten bouquets.

One night, a stray cat curled up on the bench where she used to sit. Mr. Fenwick watched the moonlight pour through the stained glass, illuminating a single train ticket wedged in the seat’s crack. It read, “To Wherever You Are.”

The stationmaster tucked it into his pocket, a silent promise. Maybe, he thought, the world is stitched together by all the unsaid farewells, the lingering scents, and the unmoved clocks. Without a goodbye, some things never truly leave. And as dawn broke, the 4:17 whistled softly, ready at last to depart into the mist.

One spring, after a violent storm, a message in a bottle washed ashore. And every year, on the anniversary of his disappearance, the ocean shone with a hundred tiny lights, flickering in the mist, refusing to let Emrys fade without a trace—even if he’d left without a goodbye.

In the Hudson?"  
"In the swimming lake."  

The confusion in Margaret’s voice was audible, but her brother didn’t slow down as he led her down the muddy trail. The morning fog clung to their shoes, and the world felt smaller, secretive.  

“I know what I saw,” he whispered.  

At the edge of the lake, the trees grew close and dark, crowding the water. Something shimmered beneath the surface. Not fish, not weeds. Margaret knelt, peering in. A glint of gold caught her eye—a ring, impossibly old, nestled in the mud.  

She reached for it, but the water stirred. A hand, cold and pale, closed over hers. Margaret gasped, paralyzed by fear as a voice echoed from the depths.  

“Return what was stolen.”  

Her brother pulled her away, both of them tumbling back on the bank. The hand retreated, the gold vanished, and the lake stilled.  

They stared at each other, hearts pounding. For a long moment, neither spoke. Then, as the sun broke through the fog, Margaret whispered, “We can never come back here.”

In the Hudson?"

"In the swimming lake."

Gerald’s voice was flat, but his eyes sparkled with mischief as he led the way down the wooded path. The trees arched overhead, their branches forming a cathedral of green. Behind them, the city roared, but here, only the soft lap of water and the hum of insects remained.

At the edge of the lake, Gerald knelt, plucking something from the reeds. It was a bottle, green glass, sealed with wax. He handed it to me, grinning. "Found it last night. Thought we’d open it together."

I hesitated, fingering the slick glass. "What if it’s dangerous?"

He laughed. "It’s not from the Hudson. It’s from here."

I broke the seal, and a thin wisp of smoke curled out, carrying a scent of salt and jasmine. The water rippled. A voice murmured, too soft to understand. Gerald’s smile faded. The lake’s reflection shimmered, showing not our faces, but a pair of unfamiliar eyes staring back.

"We should go," I whispered. But Gerald’s feet seemed rooted to the spot, as if the lake itself had claimed him.

He called her name, voice trembling. The surface broke with a ripple, just beyond his reach. Something pale, a hand perhaps, or a fish? Julian held his breath. The lantern flickered. He remembered her laughter, the way she’d dared him to swim out past the buoys.

He fled the lake, heart pounding, the lantern’s light bobbing behind him. He never spoke of what happened. But sometimes, late at night, he heard her laughter again, drifting through the open window, calling him back to the water.

"What’d you find?"

My friends screamed. I dropped the bottle and swam for shore, the water behind me churning as if alive. We never went back to the swimming lake. But sometimes, late at night, I dream of hands reaching from the depths, and wake to find lake water on my floor.

I shift in my chair, unsure whether to comfort or confess. The wind rattles the windowpanes, a thousand tiny fists demanding entry. “Sometimes I hear her laugh in the hallway,” Mr. Lamont says. “Last night, I saw her shadow on the wall. It lingered at the top of the stairs.”

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. "You know, there’s an old superstition that says if you sew a button with red thread under a new moon, you can lure a soul back home. I tried it, three times." He laughs, the sound dry as autumn leaves. "Nothing happened, of course. Except the cat wouldn’t go near the coat for weeks."

He turns his teacup slowly, gaze distant. "Grief makes you believe in all kinds of magic. I started leaving the porch light on, just in case she found her way. I even baked her favorite bread, filled the house with its scent. But the only footprints in the flour belonged to me."

He looks at me then, eyes shining. "Maybe she’s waiting, somewhere I can’t see her yet. Or maybe she’s just gone. But every evening, as the shadows grow, I find myself listening, just in case she knocks. Just in case."

Even when the frost threatened, even when the neighbors laughed.” He stares at the window, where rain streaks blur the outside world into watercolor. “I used to think she was stubborn, wasting her time.
